title: 106_hr2367
content: The Torture Victims Relief Reauthorization Act of 1999 authorizes funding for foreign treatment centers for victims of torture and domestic treatment centers. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003. The Torture Victims Relief Reauthorization Act of 1999 authorizes $10,000,000 for domestic treatment centers for victims of torture for fiscal years 2001 to 2003. The funds shall remain available until expended. The Torture Victims Relief Reauthorization Act of 1999 authorizes $5,000,000 for the United States contribution to the United Nations Voluntary Fund for Victims of Torture for fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003. The funds shall remain available until expended. The Representative to the United Nations should request the Fund to support and protect treatment centers for torture victims, encourage the development of new centers, support the work of the Special Rapporteur on Torture and the Committee Against Torture, and establish a country rapporteur to investigate human rights violations in countries with systematic torture practices. SEC. 5. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The Secretary of State must submit a report to the Senate and House committees on specialized training for foreign service officers as required by the Torture Victims Relief Act of 1998. The report should detail efforts to implement the training, the curriculum used, the number of officers trained, and the involvement of NGOs in developing and providing the training. Technical amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, specifically redesignating section 129 as section 130. Additionally, amendments are made to the Torture Victims Relief Act of 1998 to reflect this change. The Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate are involved in these amendments.
